column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#Text=[0029] Each origin server 110-112 generally stores and is adapted to serve web content or pages, also referred to as sites or applications.
#Text=The clients 130-134 can generate requests or queries for the content of any one of the various sites served by the origin servers.
#Text=For example, a user 130 may desire to log into or access an application that is served by origin server 110.
#Text=[0030] A session is generally defined as an active communication, measured from beginning to end, between devices and applications over a network.
#Text=A client 130-134 can initiate a session by sending a query or request for the web content, which can also be referred to as logging in.
#Text=The query can be embodied as Hypertext transport protocol ("HTTP") request.
#Text=The HTTP response can include for example, a "SET COOKIE" header request that defines certain values related to the response, such as for example, <name> <value> <domain> <path> <time out>.
#Text=The SET COOKIE flag can be used to generate the header that is used to establish the session.
#Text=The contents from the response header injected is important because it established a session.
#Text=The cache array 150 can parse the header for this cookie that has been set for the directives as to what to do with the content, which is served from one of the origin servers 110-112.

#Text=[0031] The disclosed embodiments are generally adapted to maintain the loose coupling of the cluster array and encapsulate the session state and session binding information to make proper session state decision in a cookie.
#Text=A "cookie" is a mechanism that is a feature of the Hypertext Transport Protocol ("HTTP") used in the Internet and the WWW, and is a term that is well known and used in the art.
#Text=For this methodology, a client must generally have cookies enabled for their browser.
#Text=[0032] There are two basic pieces of data or information maintained in the cookie.
#Text=The first piece of information is an identifier that is a unique identity of the coupled array of webcaches 102-108 of FIG. 1.
#Text=[0033] Generally, a unique identifier needs to be assigned to the entire cluster.
#Text=A cluster identifier ("CID") can be used in hierarchical caching.
#Text=Since each cache member generally knows the entire member list, the cluster 150 can use the (ip, port) of the lowest (or highest) ranking "live" cache as the CID for the entire cluster.
#Text=This "enhanced" CID works even in situations where a network partition splits the cluster into two.
#Text=The key here is that whatever name is used it is unique to the cluster and every member knows that name.
#Text=This is used to evaluate if the session information is the information for this particular cluster.
#Text=Additionally we are flexible in configuration changes and actively partition the cooperation of the loosely coupled array.
#Text=A mechanism should be included to ensure that the list of backend servers that generate content do not change.
